awd_titl_txt: CC* Compute: Improved Computing for Advanced Research and Education (ICARE)
awd_abstract_narration:
University researchers and educators require access to high performance computing, high bandwidth connections, sharable storage, and high-throughput data transfers. Unfortunately, institutional cyberinfrastructures can be silos of dissimilar and unconnected computing resources, with limited functionality, and inconsistent service delivery. The Improved Computing for Advanced Research and Education (ICARE) team addresses these issues and advances discovery and understanding by serving as a shared high-throughput computing site. Information Technology (IT) professionals and the scientific research community work together to coordinate campus-level cyberinfrastructure improvements based on project-driven needs. These include scientific research projects that improve natural disaster forecasting, produce innovative modeling tools used for maintaining biodiversity, impact the design of nuclear receptor drugs used to treat many diseases, develop deep learning approaches to DNA sequencing, and explore genomic responses to climate change.

The main feature of ICARE is the UM Shared Computing Cluster (UMSCC). UMSCC is configured with 8 computing nodes, 3 GPU nodes, and 2 storage nodes. Open source software solutions and participation in the Open Science Grid (OSG) facilitates data intensive research and extends computing resources to internal and external research groups, graduate and undergraduate researchers, and the nation. This effort strengthens collaboration between diverse groups of researchers and provides a vehicle for ongoing discussion and planning between IT professionals, educators, and researchers. A special aspect of this project is the direct relationship between IT professionals and the campus scientific research community, which is providing sound IT solutions that are critical for future competitiveness in grant funding and academic contribution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
University faculty require regular access to high performance computing and a network capable of high-throughput data transfers in order to conduct research. Unfortunately, institutional cyberinfrastructures can be silos of dissimilar computing resources with limited functionality and inconsistent service delivery. A team of University of Montana (UM) Information Technology (IT) professionals and researchers came together to identify cyberinfrastructure needs and limitations as related to several diverse research efforts. These included scientific research projects that improve natural disaster forecasting, produce innovative biodiversity modeling tools, impact the design of drugs, develop deep learning approaches to DNA sequencing, and projects exploring genomic responses to climate change. This effort resulted in the Improved Computing for Advanced Research and Education (ICARE) proposal to deploy UM’s first high-performance shared compute cluster.

The ICARE project received funding to purchase the Griz Shared Compute Cluster (GSCC) in support of research at UM. The major goals were to acquire and deploy the GSCC and to ensure research projects justifying this effort could use the cluster to advance scientific discovery.

The GSCC, deployed by January 2020, provides 16 computing nodes and 12 GPU nodes. In addition, the cluster has 2 storage nodes, 1 head node and 2 login nodes. The cluster utilizes an internal 10 GbE switch for internal processing and communications between the computing and GPU nodes. Since the announcement of the award, 26 additional compute nodes have been donated to the cluster. Within the project timeline, 124 users have accessed the GSCC. Slurm statistics show that 690,484,179 compute minutes have ran on the cluster, which equates to approximately 500,000 compute days of activity. The ICARE project was driven by the infrastructure and compute needs of five researchers from Computer Science, Biological Science, and Geoscience. All five are currently using the GSCC and have reported the following:

Driver 1: Hilary R. Martens – Probing Earth structure using geodetic measurements of surface mass loading – “The GSCC has been instrumental to advancing our work on Earth's deformation response to ocean tidal loading. The GSCC has completely transformed our ability to process large amounts of GPS data efficiently, and therefore to advance the science of oceanic loading and deformation more rapidly than previously possible.”

Driver 2: Erin L. Landguth - Computational Ecology Lab projects – The GSCC has been used as a computational resource for several Ecology Lab projects. This includes Brook Trout simulations testing fitness effects on EBT recovery, simulations testing the effects of barriers and life history on genetic structure and diversity of Bull Trout reintroduction. 

Driver 3: Travis Hughes - Understanding the mechanistic basis of nuclear receptor drug efficacy – The Hughes Lab has “performed ~1 ms total sampling, using accelerated molecular dynamics and conventional molecular dynamics, of nuclear receptors bound to several different agonists. These data have allowed us to formulate and test hypotheses regarding how agonists induce nuclear receptors to preferentially bind select cofactor proteins. The GPUs in the Griz cluster sample at about 2-fold the speed of the other GPUs that we can access. This increased sampling speed has allowed us to more completely sample ms motions using accelerated molecular dynamics.”

Driver 4: Travis Wheeler - Machine Learning Approaches to Improve Sensitivity and Error in Sequence Annotation – “We’ve used the cluster for: massive scale sequence annotation efforts for human and metagenome datasets [and] large scale analysis of small molecules and their binding affinity to protein targets.”

Driver 5: Jeffrey M. Good - Three genomic studies aimed at understanding the origin and evolution of complex traits in mammals – “Access to the GSCC has had transformative impact across several studies in the Good laboratory. One of the key project drivers was a large comparative genomic study examining gene evolution across 220 rodent species. We have also used the GSCC to conduct systems genetics studies on placental development and testicular function using rodent models. These studies have shed new insights into how pathways of gene expression evolve and influence embryonic development and male fertility.”

Along with enabling the scientific research used to justify this grant, the GSCC is making a broader impact. Research faculty have demonstrated that the GSCC is an exceptional experiential-learning platform for preparing students to conduct research. Within the project timeline, there were 35 students actively analyzing data and running simulations on the GSCC. This aspect of the project builds researcher capacity and will undoubtably contribute to the quality of research moving forward. Researchers utilizing the GSCC have disseminated their findings through eleven publications to date, revealing the diversity of societal issues that can be addressed through research using the GSCC.
